Award.AwardTitle: Developing Students' Troubleshooting Skills in Energy Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PARTNERING INSTITUTIONS: Northern Oklahoma College, Sowela Technical Community College, Houston Community College, Bismarck State College, and the University of Alaska


PROJECT DESCRIPTION
The Northern Oklahoma College and partners across five states are developing problem-based equipment, process, and systems troubleshooting instructional modules for various energy degree programs. The goal of the team is increasing students' knowledge and enhancing their demonstrated skills in troubleshooting; with the objective of improving safety, impact on the environment, and efficiency in the energy industry.

Unfortunately, there have been a number of accidents during the past few years as evidenced by the investigative studies conducted by the U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board (CSB). A recent scan within the broader energy industry revealed incidents in the oil and gas, power generation, ethanol production, and biodiesel production sectors. Thus, the ability to enhance troubleshooting skills is needed for the nation to develop a highly competent energy workforce, maintain the consistent production of energy, lessen the dependence on foreign energy sources and contribute to the security and safety of the energy facilities.

In response to this need, the partnership is designing, developing and implementing 18 generic equipment scenarios and 16 process/system-specific troubleshooting instructional modules for energy technicians that can either be: 1) used as stand-alone modules or 2) integrated into a capstone course for college students. The modules are providing students with an opportunity to acquire relevant troubleshooting knowledge and skills that prepare them to handle process upsets while working in the energy industry. Furthermore, students are able to showcase their acquired troubleshooting skills during a simulator competition.


BROADER SIGNIFICANCE
This effort is having a significant impact by: (1) providing professional development for subject matter experts from colleges and industry to ensure competency in designing/developing instructional materials and teaching troubleshooting modules; (2) promoting national security and energy independence by providing a highly skilled and educated energy technician workforce; and (3) disseminating insights on students' critical thinking and troubleshooting skills to the education community. The project's influence covers a large geographical area; while the developed modules can be easily used in community college settings as well as industrial in-house training programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project grant #1457711, Developing Students’ Troubleshooting Skills in Energy Programs, was awarded to help eliminate a gap in workforce skills of employees in the energy industry. Specifically to enhance the troubleshooting skills of advanced level Process Technology students or incumbent industry employees needing refresher training in process troubleshooting. This project was defined by its diverse and instrumental use of subject matter experts to incorporate processes critical to industry. The greater impact is the promotion of national security and energy independence by providing a highly skilled and educated technician workforce. This grant was hosted by Lone Star College – Kingwood in Kingwood, Texas.

The two main goals and deliverables associated with this project grant are:

  • Design, develop and implement 10 generic equipment-related and 17 process-specific or system-specific troubleshooting instructional modules for energy technicians used as stand-alone modules or integrated into a capstone course for college students.
  • Provide an opportunity for students to showcase the troubleshooting skills acquired during an energy degree program.

The Process Troubleshooting Skills in Energy Consortium worked with college and industry members located nationwide to create learning materials for use in advanced college courses and by industry trainers. The troubleshooting modules consist of an Instructor Lesson Plan and a companion Student Learning Plan. The learning materials are available as open-source product via download from the world-wide web.

The materials are written as mock scenarios that can, and do, happen at real world industry plant sites. They help promote and enhance the process troubleshooting skills of advanced Process Technology students prior to entering the workforce, and are suitable for use by industry representatives in refresher training for incumbent employees.

A competition event, also developed under this project grant, is the National Troubleshooting Skills Competition. Qualifying students showcased their troubleshooting skills at the national level using a simulated process format.

Major Accomplishments

  • Developed ten general equipment modules – basic and advanced level
  • Developed seventeen process specific modules
  • Developed the National Troubleshooting Competition event held annually each year during the grant tenure

National Troubleshooting Competition

An annual competition, developed for advanced level students in Process Technology programs across the nation, has been hosted each year on a partner college campus. The competition consists of a Qualifying Round completed via the web using a learning management system. The top eight teams are selected by scoring utility and earn the right to represent their college at the National Final Competition. This National Finals event was designed to be conducted on simulators using animated software models of process plant operations.

The event has grown each year as eight teams participated the first year, thirteen teams the second year, and twenty nine teams in its third year.

An industry networking hour was added in the third year to the National Finals event to help students understand the importance, and value, of having good soft [people] skills as they enter the workforce.

Learning Materials

Troubleshooting modules cover operations topics of equipment, instrumentation, and process specific systems. These standalone materials are currently being utilized by college instructors and industry trainers to enhance the troubleshooting skills of individuals being prepared to enter the workforce or, by individuals who currently are responsible for process operating units.

Sustainability

To ensure the deliverables of the grant are sustained and have a path forward for growth, the North American Process Technology Alliance has taken stewardship of the PTSE website, learning materials, and the National Troubleshooting Competition. The Alliance will maintain and update the learning materials and will assume responsibility for the competition event in the coming year.
